title: Impact of COVID-19 on Sleep
content: The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted sleep in 3 ways: The amount that people are sleeping, the timing of the sleep, and dreaming. Total sleep time had increased across the entire country by ~20%. Social 'jet lag' had decreased. Subjective sleep quality had decreased in a subset of people. People were going to bed about 30 minutes later and waking up about 50 minutes later the next morning. People have been reporting having more dreams since the pandemic began.

title: Importance of Dreaming for Emotional Health
content: Dreaming has increased during the coronavirus pandemic due to two reasons: Timing of sleep and dreaming allows for the purging negative emotion or stress. REM sleep is typically associated with dreaming. These are the dreams we think of as narrative-based, emotionally-filled, bizarre, hallucinogenic, dreams. One of the principle functions of rapid eye movement sleep that we now have understood is that it seems to provide a form of overnight therapy. REM sleep tries to take the sharp edges off difficult experiences so that when you come back the next day without feeling as emotional as you did about those events the day before.

title: The Importance of REM Sleep
content: REM sleep is emotional first aid. It’s not time that heals all wounds. It’s actually time during REM sleep and dreaming that provides this emotional convalescence. Sleep is responsive—it’s what we call homeostatically regulated, but also homeostatically reflexive. If something happens during the day that requires more of a specific stage of sleep, then sleep will respond by giving the brain a little bit more of that sleep to deal with it. This applies to learning and memory, skill-learning tasks, and emotional experiences.

title: The Impact of Alcohol on Sleep Quality
content: Alcohol consumption can negatively impact sleep quality. Using sleep trackers, it can be observed that sleep quality suffers if more than one drink is consumed too close to bedtime. Heart rate variability gets crushed, resting heart rate goes up by 10-25%, respiratory rate is up two breaths per minute, and core body temperature is up half a degree. Alcohol also disproportionately negatively impacts REM sleep. This creates a situation where alcohol, which may be used to numb anxiety, impairs the ability to have REM sleep, which is exactly the medicine needed.

title: How Alcohol Disrupts Sleep
content: Alcohol is a sedative—You actually “lose consciousness” faster when you put yourself in bed, but you’re not going into naturalistic sleep. Your sleep becomes more fragmented because the alcohol will actually stimulate the fight or flight branch of the nervous system which are wake promoting chemicals making you wake up more frequently throughout the night. Alcohol will decrease the amount of REM sleep that you get. If you’re downscaling the amount of REM sleep that you get at night with alcohol, you may not be getting the necessary emotional benefit that you need to de-risk the emotional experiences and the anxiety that’s building up.

title: Genetic Differences in Alcohol's Impact on Sleep
content: Alcohol impacts people differently. Some people are fast metabolizers of alcohol (same with caffeine). And in those fast-metabolizers, by the time their brain is ready for REM sleep, the metabolic consequences of alcohol degradation—the aldehydes and ketones—are no longer present. Of course, there are also people who have one drink at 3pm and it “crushes” their REM sleep.

title: Sleep's Impact on the Immune System
content: Sleep improves immune function. There is a very intimate association between your sleep health and your immune health. Individuals getting less than seven hours of sleep a night are almost three times more likely to become infected by the rhinovirus (common cold). A large prospective study of over 50,000 women found that women who were sleeping 5 hours or less were 70% more likely to develop pneumonia (a component risk in the equation of COVID). When mice are selectively deprived mice of various stages of sleep (particularly REM sleep) and exposed to malaria, they were far more likely to die as a consequence compared to the well-rested mice.

title: Sleep and Vaccination Efficacy
content: A study looking at response to flu vaccines found that not getting sufficient sleep in the week before you get your flu shot resulted in producing less than 50% of the normal antibody response therefore rendering that flu vaccination significantly less effective. This suggests that sleep could increase the efficacy of vaccinations, including a potential COVID-19 vaccine.

title: Determining Deep Sleep and REM Sleep Needs
content: For deep, non-REM sleep, how much deep sleep you need/get is determined by how long you’ve been awake and only a little bit on the basis of your circadian rhythm. REM sleep is much more powerfully determined by the circadian time of night and is less determined by how long you’ve been awake.

title: The Role of Melatonin, Cortisol, and Adenosine in Sleep
content: The amount of deep sleep you need is somewhat a function of the accumulation of melatonin, how much cortisol you’ve managed to suppress, and very much a function of the accumulation of adenosine. Adenosine is a chemical that starts building up in your brain the moment you wake up. And the longer the amount of clock time that your brain has been awake, the more adenosine builds up. This produces what we call “sleep pressure”.

title: Pros and Cons of Napping
content: Naps as short as 17 minutes can produce learning and memory benefits and you can some benefit from a cardiovascular standpoint as well. The downside of naps is that it can take away which is sleep pressure which could exacerbate nighttime sleep issues. If you are struggling with falling asleep at night (sleep onset insomnia), avoid naps during the day. On the flip side, if you are not struggling with your sleep at night, there’s no problem with napping regularly during the day.

title: Sleep Hygiene and Tips for Better Sleep
content: Five main sleep hygiene tips include regularity, light, temperature, walking it out, and avoiding alcohol/caffeine. Going to bed at the same time, waking up at the same time. Getting lots of darkness at night because we are a dark-deprived society (and making sure you get daylight during the first half of the day). You need to get cool to get to sleep. Don’t lie awake in bed because trains your brain to be triggered by your bed and force you awake because you have a learned association. Avoid alcohol and caffeine too close to bedtime.

title: Improving Sleep Performance
content: Building a routine into your sleep schedule can be beneficial. This routine might include light stretches, meditation, and putting away all phones and gadgets. If you are struggling with sleep, remove all clock faces from your bedroom. This can help reduce anxiety. Technology, especially phones, can cause 'anticipatory anxiety' and result in 'sleep procrastination'. Setting manageable goals can also help improve sleep. These tips are for improving your sleep performance, and are for people without a sleep disorder. If you do have an actual sleep disorder (insomnia, apnea, etc.) you need to get help from a physician.

title: Understanding Sleep Chronotypes
content: Your sleep chronotype refers to whether you are a morning person, an evening person, or somewhere in between. Sleep science breaks it into 4 categories: Extreme morning types, Morning types, Middle evening types, Extreme evening types. There is a significant degree of heritability and a collection of genes that will determine, to a degree, your chronotype. Your innate chronotype can still be twisted/contorted by non-genetic forces such as modern social norms, light exposure, technology, etc.

title: Night Terrors in Kids
content: Night terrors are typically where people (mostly kids) wake up with a terrible sense of dread and fear. The night terror events seem to happen during deep non-REM sleep (i.e., dreamless sleep) rather than during REM sleep. When a child spends an extended time being awake or miss a nap, they will typically then have a homeostatic increase in the amount of deep sleep. This therefore means that the probabilistic likelihood of them having one of these night terrors is increased as a consequence.

title: Addressing Errors in Sleep Research
content: There are several errors in sleep research that need to be addressed. These include the association between sleep and cardiovascular disease, the relationship between short sleep and cancer risk, the relationship between sleep deprivation and depression, the relationship between sleep loss and cardiovascular disease, the relationship between sleep loss/short sleep and cardiac arrests, the relationship between long sleep and mortality risk, and the claim that the WHO classified any form of nighttime shift work as a probable carcinogen.
